Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Collaborative Research: RUI: Human-Centered Semantic Relatedness

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This work addresses key open questions about semantic relatedness (SR) measures, a family of algorithms used throughout computer science and related fields that help computers replicate human assessments of the relatedness between two concepts. Decades of research and development have transformed SR measures into a critical component of a wide swath of intelligent technologies in areas ranging from information retrieval to human-computer interaction to spatial computing. However, despite the importance and ubiquity of SR, researchers have only recently begun to examine it from a human-centered perspective. These human-centered studies have problematized key assumptions underlying the entire SR literature, e.g. that people from all cultural contexts agree on a single relatedness value between any two concepts. This project addresses long-overdue open questions in the SR literature that will move the field towards a more human-centered approach to SR. To do so, this research will collect datasets of relatedness judgments, mine patterns in Wikipedia and other content, perform statistical analyses, create and evaluate algorithms, develop software, and conduct large-scale user studies.

First, this research will complete four threads of work that redefine semantic relatedness to address human-centered concerns raised in the SR literature: (1) investigate the role of culture in SR and use these results to redefine SR to incorporate cultural context, (2) study SR among the low-notability concepts that are critical to end users but entirely ignored by the SR literature, (3) address the need for SR measures that explain their relatedness estimates to users, and (4) develop more robust human-centered SR evaluation procedures and support their adoption through easy-to-use software. Second, this research will develop new conceptual representations for SR measures that accommodate differing cultural perspectives and create compact contextual SR models that empower applications with tractable human-centered SR algorithms. Finally, the research will demonstrate the power of human-centered SR approaches through their application in improved recommender systems, enhanced Wikipedia reader experiences, and novel information discovery tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work addresses key open questions about semantic relatedness (SR) measures, a family of algorithms used throughout computer science and related fields. SR measures estimate how related two words, concepts, or phrases are. For example, an accurate SR measure may estimate that "apple" and "dog" have a relatedness of 0.1 (very low), while "apple" and "orange" have a relatedness of 0.9 (very high). Decades of research and development have transformed SR measures into a critical component for technologies ranging from search engines, to assistive conversational bots, to geo-spatial algorithms that find restaurants that are similar to ones that you like.

However, despite the importance and widespread use of SR, researchers have only recently begun to understand the human dimensions of how they are used. For example, little is known about how well the same SR measure serves people from different culture backgrounds.

This grant supported human-centered advances to SR. Through experimental studies, we found the first clear evidence that people from different cultural backgrounds perceive SR differently, and created algorithms that meet these differences. We also advanced SR accuracy through the creation of two new algorithms inspired from developments in the fields of natural language processing, recommender systems, and geography.

We built upon these human-centered SR advances to create new computer science applications and innovations:

  • We measured the geographic focus and degree of geographic bias inherent in information on Wikipedia and Google search results. 
  • We leveraged relationships between SR algorithms and explicit, human-created knowledge bases such as Open Street Map and Wikidata (the editable knowledge base associated with Wikipedia). By synthesizing these two ideas, we could design editing systems for knowledge bases that harness human power more effectively than traditional editing approaches.
  • We simulated and evaluated data strikes, a new type of collective action that the public could take against algorithms that rely on their data.
  • We created a visualization technique that uses SR to create interactive "map-based" visualizations from data that is not inherently spatial. We evaluated our visualization and found it exceeds upon prior approaches. 

In addition to these scientific discoveries, this grant supported specific outcomes and products. The research described above has been shared through 11 different papers published in high-impact academic journals and conferences. The computational workstations and servers used to conduct this research have supported the creation of a state-of-the-art data science computing lab at Macalester College. This work has also resulted in two public software products. The WikiBrain software library, which provides a platform for Wikipedia-based SR algorithms, has been downloaded and used thousands of times. The Cartograph visualization website enables users to identify patterns among millions of Wikipedia articles, such as the gender focus of those articles. 

Finally, this grant has supported 20 transformative undergraduate student research experiences, including 12 for women. These students worked collaboratively as a team during intensive summer research experiences. They received training that improves both their research abilities and their "core" computer science skills in areas such as algorithmic analysis, data science, and software engineering.
